properties.description: Up to 90% of people living with dementia will experience distressed behaviour as a result of unmet needs, but the majority of it is preventable. We’ve built the first AI tool that predicts distressed behaviour in dementia care, before it happens, giving carers real-time & evidence-based support to prevent distress, prevent crises, reduce medication, and meet people's needs effectively.
properties.how_does_your_company_use_innovation__th:
We’re combining behavioural science with machine learning to do something that hasn’t been done before in dementia care: predict distressed behaviour before it happens.

Instead of waiting for things to go wrong and reacting in crisis, Less Distress is an app that uses real-world care data to spot early warning signs and guide carers in real time. It’s personalised, preventative, and based on the science of why behaviour happens in the first place, something most systems completely ignore.

Our innovation isn’t just in the tech, it’s in the model. We’re giving frontline carers access to the kind of behavioural insight that’s usually locked away in specialist services, and doing it in a way that’s fast, affordable, easy to use on the job, and a globally scalable solution.
properties.how_does_your_product_contribute_to_a_he:
Less Distress is about making things better for everyone involved in dementia care: The person, the carer, and the family.

All behaviour happens for a reason. In dementia, that reason is often an unmet need, but it’s very hard for carers to understand what the need is without proper training (which they very rarely receive). We help carers see what the behaviour is trying to say, so they can respond in a way that meets the need, not just manages the reaction.

When carers can predict distress before it happens, they can step in early and calmly, rather than reacting in crisis. Right now, when distressed behaviour is difficult for carers to support with, people are given unlicensed antipsychotics just to keep them sedated even though the side effects can be devastating: sedation, stroke, and death. It’s not person-centred care, it’s damage control.

Less Distress helps change that. We give carers real tools, grounded in behavioural science, so they can reduce medication, prevent placement breakdowns, and support the person effectively. That means more dignity, more calm, and more moments where people feel understood, not lost.

When it feels like no one cares...emwillcare
properties.name: emwillcare
properties.please_expand:
I’m not just looking for money, I’m looking for real partnership that brings not just funding, but support, mentorship, and guidance from people who’ve done this before and can help me take what I’ve started and turn it into something huge.

The AI company we’re working with built our prototype for free, and they’re still developing with us at no cost, because they believe in what we’re doing. It's the same with our marketing support. People are giving their time and skills because they’ve seen the impact that I have as a behaviour analyst, and they believe in me to make it happen.

In July, I’ll be pitching to investors for the first time at an Alzheimer’s Society event. I know my field, I’m one of only 80 behavioural analysts in the world who specialise in dementia. What I need now is someone who can help me build this into a service that’s available to everyone who needs it at a devastating time in their life.

I’m here to deliver and I’m the right person for this job. I’ll be the best entrepreneur you’ve ever worked with. I care for the people I help and want to make their lives better on a wider scale than I can do in-person. I make change happen, I’ve done it all my life (I started my other business 4 years ago, the first behavioural consultancy business in the UK for dementia care). And now I’m ready to do it on a much bigger scale to help millions of people.
properties.what_best_describes_your_stage_of_busine: I have a business that I want to scale
properties.what_is_your_usp__what_makes_you_differe:
There are currently no competitors in the field. I’m one of only 80 behaviour analysts in the whole world specialising in dementia care, and I’ve spent years working directly with carers, trying to stop distress before it spirals into crisis. However, there is only so many people I can help in-person.

'Less Distress', by emwillcare takes my knowledge and expertise and is the first tool that actually predicts distressed behaviour using behavioural science and AI, not just tracking what’s already gone wrong, but helping carers know what to do next, in real time. This isn’t just innovation, it’s a lifeline for caregivers.

We are supported by the Alzheimer's Society Launchpad programme, and Business Wales Accelerator Growth Programme.
properties.where_is_your_business_based_: UK but wanting to scale to US

structured_data.executive_summary: Revolutionising Dementia Care with Behavioural Science & AI. Predict Distress. Prevent Crisis. Support Carers.
structured_data.problem_statement: Inappropriate use of unlicensed antipsychotic drugs (with nasty side effects) for behavioural issues, Inability to support with behaviours resulting from dementia leads to increased care costs, Dementia care costs the UK £34.7 billion/year, Expected to hit £94.1 billion by 2040
structured_data.solution: The digital healthcare platform that automates the process of assessing and preventing distressed behaviours for people with dementia, Based on evidence-based scientific principles, A recommendation engine provides personalised, actionable strategies
structured_data.product_service_description: AI-powered behavioural support for dementia carers, Caregivers log distressed behaviours & AI-driven behavioural science identifies triggers & patterns, Reduces distress, improves care, and prevents unnecessary medication
structured_data.traction_milestones: Run pilot in care homes, Build MVP digital platform, Position for larger NHS & care provider contracts, AI model refinement using real-world data

company_profile.description: At emwillcare, our mission is to transform dementia care by ensuring that individuals living with dementia receive the best possible support.
key_products_services: Direct consultancy services to support people caring for those with dementia
company_profile.target_customer: Caregivers working in residential or domiciliary settings, or supporting family members with dementia
company_profile.location_hq: North West GB, North Wales GB
company_profile.mission_statement: To transform dementia care by ensuring that individuals living with dementia receive the best possible support.

market_analysis.industry_overview: The healthcare and life sciences industry encompasses a wide range of sectors and disciplines that focus on improving human health and well-being. It includes the creation, commercialization, and delivery of medical products, services, and technologies. The industry is one of the world's largest and fastest-growing, consuming over 10% of GDP in most developed countries. Key segments include pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, medical devices, diagnostics, and healthcare services.
market_analysis.target_market_segment: The healthcare and life sciences industry serves a diverse range of customers, including patients, healthcare providers, payers, researchers, and regulatory bodies. It caters to the needs of the global population, with a focus on improving access to quality healthcare, addressing chronic diseases, and advancing personalized medicine.
key_market_trends: Growth of personalized medicine and biotechnology
Expansion of digital health and remote monitoring
Increasing focus on sustainability and addressing global healthcare needs
market_analysis.competitor_landscape_summary: The healthcare and life sciences industry is highly competitive, with a mix of large multinational corporations, specialized biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies, and emerging startups. Key players include Thermo Fisher Scientific, Danaher, Roche, Merck, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson, Agilent, Illumina, Becton Dickinson, and Bio-Rad Laboratories. These companies compete on factors such as innovation, product quality, pricing, and market access.

competitors.name: Danaher Corporation
strengths: Expertise in life sciences and diagnostics

competitors.name: Roche Holding AG
strengths: Strong pipeline of innovative pharmaceuticals and diagnostics
Leadership in oncology and personalized medicine

company_competitive_advantages: Expertise in personalized medicine and biotechnology
Ability to address global healthcare needs and sustainability
Strong market position and brand recognition
barriers_to_entry: High capital requirements for R&D and manufacturing
Stringent regulatory environment and lengthy approval processes
Established relationships with healthcare providers and payers
Intellectual property protection and patent barriers
market_analysis.regulatory_environment: The healthcare and life sciences industry is heavily regulated, with various national and international bodies overseeing the development, approval, and commercialization of medical products and services. Key regulatory aspects include clinical trial requirements, product safety and efficacy standards, data privacy and security, and reimbursement policies. Navigating this complex regulatory landscape is a significant barrier to entry for new players.
